The problem with that argument colin (which you started to discuss), is that
it assumes that the crackpots betting on the planetary cycles keep their
money long enough to keep affecting the market.

To have any noticeable impact on the market, there would have to be a TON of
these people betting a lot of money over a long period of time....what % of
overall trades are influenced by astrology? It is probably 5 (or more)
orders of magnitude too small to matter vs. all the other variables that
drive the market . 




Best regards,
Jeff Clune

Postdoctoral Fellow
Hod Lipson's Computational Synthesis Laboratory
Cornell University
jeffclune@...
www.msu.edu/~jclune

> From: Colin Green <colin.green1@...>
> Reply-To: "neat@yahoogroups.com" <neat@yahoogroups.com>
> Date: Sat, 6 Nov 2010 17:30:43 +0000
> To: "neat@yahoogroups.com" <neat@yahoogroups.com>
> Subject: Re: [neat] Re: Financial trading with Hyperneat
> 
> On 5 November 2010 22:17, William Wilson <fluffysheap@...> wrote:
>> 
>> Better example would be this:
>> http://members.cox.net/mathmistakes/glossary1.htm#Shooting
>> 
>> Given enough data, it's possible to find correlations to practically
>> anything, but that does not mean there is any predictive power.
>> 
>> You might also be interested in/amused by:
>> http://xkcd.com/552/
>> http://xkcd.org/808/
>> 
> 
> Yup, am an xkcd reader :)
> 
> Yes I'll admit that finding correlations and assuming they have
> predictive power is a far more common mistake. But I still stand by my
> argument that just because astrology is nonsense doesn't mean it
> wouldn't have actual predictive power - so long as enough people
> believed in it and applied it. Of course on aggragte they will be
> playing a zero sum game (no-one wins overall and transaction costs
> mean the average player loses), and then smarter folks predict once
> step ahead and then two steps, etc and the system decends back into
> chaotic noise.
> 
> I think I just disproved my argument(*) :)
> 
> * - in the long run. This might still work over a given time period,
> that is, until enough people catch on.
> 
> Colin.
